Ah ok I understand better.

I have used a setUp() method that receives a set of indexes that 
determine which static DataSet[index] to use. Given that I have the 
large data set handled, do you still feel it is worth tackling this 
type of testing using JUnit?? I have certain services that return 
objects that correspond to a collection of API calls. So I compare 
the two and assert that their states are the same. 
Thanks,
Claudio










--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> claudioillanes wrote:
> 
> > 
> > 
> > Hello Everyone,
> > 
> > I'd like to ask all experienced developers out there for some
> > feedback regarding using JUnit for integration/system testing.
> > I am really not familiar with other system/integration testing
> > packages. I have a large app that basically wraps an API. The 
testing
> > that has to get setup needs to compare states between the app and 
the
> > API to ensure that all business rules comply at every state. Is 
this
> > something that JUnit can/should do? The app has many different 
states
> > that I would have to setUp() but I'd like to know if using JUnit 
is
> > the most effective way of testing this way?
> 
> With JUnit, you simply send your application input and check its 
output. 
> The advantage to using JUnit is the ability to write the tests in 
Java, 
> rather than some home-grown pseudo-scripting language (such as 
WinRunner 
> provides). If the testing is largely data-driven, though, you may 
wish 
> to consider using Fit/FitNesse (fitnesse.org). Here, "data-driven" 
> means, for example, that you have one test algorithm to run with 
100 
> different rows of test input/expected output. Fit is much better at 
that 
> than JUnit is.
